Why is DDR2 so much cheaper then DDR when it is significently faster and uses less power?
Easier to make? Bigger demand? Or a combination.

When launched, DDR2 was far more expensive, just as DDR3 is much more expensive now.
 
 Since most major factories have switched to DDR2 production there is an enormous quantity of cheap chinese ram flooding the market, competition is very strong and its price fluctuates almost like a commodity, whereas buyers are looking at a relatively small pool of DDR to buy from boutique manufacturers.
 
 You may ask, why don't the big players start making DDR if there's more money in it, but I imagine they find it difficult to clear stock - retailers don't want large quantities of it, and it isn't a long term solution. Retool your plant to make DDR, and in two years you'll have to switch it over to something else.

 I came somewhat to that conclusion but there are still some issues with it. DDR is going for about double for the same quantity as DDR2. Is there that much of a glut to warrant such a massive difference? Even on DDR2 that is comparable speed of DDR, the price is 50% off or more. It seems to me that for that to exist, the glut must be massive.

Why is DDR2 so much cheaper then DDR when it is significently faster and uses less power?

 
 Maybe they found easier ways to mass produce it at less cost?

Maybe they found easier ways to mass produce it at less cost?

 
 Then DDR? Not likely. The stuff is essentially the same stuff with some minor modifications.

It happens all the time with RAM, it's pretty much purely a supply and demand thing. The most popular RAM of the minute is the lowest price, with prices creeping up in both directions either side. Look at the price per megabyte of a 72 pin SIMM from an original pentium it will make your hair stand on end.

 But the differences between medium speed DDR2 and top end DDR aren't radically different. Low speed DDR2 is actually SLOWER then most of the DDR on the market. The only thing that makes sense is the DDR2 1200 being more expensive then high end DDR.
